预修课程

主要内容
本课程内容主要包括中国传统工艺史和外国工艺史，以及当代中国大师级工匠的成长经历。
通过本课程，学生将了解中国青铜器、陶瓷、雕漆、染织、牙雕、家具、金银器加工中的基本工艺原理和工艺流程，以及影响工艺传统变革演进的各种因素；了解外国主要文明区域不同历史时期工艺的代表作品、基本特征、传承关系，以及影响工艺传统变革演进的各种因素。
教学中，特别关注工艺传统及其发展与诸多自然和社会因素之间的关系，尤其是环境、民族、宗教、时代等因素对工艺风格特征的形成和发展的影响，使学生体悟人类在工艺传统中所沉淀的认识自然、认识自我的智慧，以及工匠透过技艺在作品中表达的对生的喜悦、对物的珍惜。工艺史不但是物质文化和精神文化的发展历史，同时，工艺史也是技术发展史的一部分。工艺产品的材料和技艺也将是本课程关注始终的要点。
本课程力求在课堂上展示大量的国内外出土文物图片和博物馆藏品图片，引导学生鉴赏分析这些图片，让学生直观地了解中外工艺的发展历程，获得对工艺制品的造型、色彩、材质的感性认识，以及对由它们所构成的工艺品的适用性和美感的鉴赏能力。
本课程的开设意在提高理工科学生的人文素养，拓展其文化视野。

教学目的要求

学生应通过课程学习，了解世界不同文化之间的相互作用机制、共生共变的历史趋势以及其中的重要历史事件与进程。

预修课程
世界历史（上）

主要内容
本教程分为20讲，每讲2学时，讲授从古代埃及、苏美尔到文艺复兴时代的世界历史。
本教程从全球文化史与思想史视角解析世界不同文化的特征与思想传统，考察不同文化之间的相互作用进程，提示人类文化共生共变的历史进程。

第一讲、1500年以来世界体系的演变
第二讲、三十年战争与欧洲民族国家的兴起：欧洲政治革命、近代民族国家的形成、帝国时代的开启
第三讲、大航海与全球化的开端：大航海运动、殖民主义、新大陆的开拓、东亚-西欧两大文化圈的联通
第四讲、科学革命（上）：科学革命的智力基础、进程、全球性影响；天文学革命（哥白尼、伽利略、开普勒）（伽利略科学探索背后的本体论承诺与方法论）
第五讲、科学革命（中）：笛卡儿构建新科学的纲领、英国皇家学会的实验哲学纲领（培根、波义耳）
第六讲、科学革命（下）：牛顿、现代科学文化的产生

教学目的要求
按照教育部2017年最新版的大学英语教学指南，大学英语II遵循较高要求，通过课堂教学和课外辅导提高学术英语读写水平。
1. 通过大量的学术阅读，帮助学生掌握英文逻辑框架和地道表达方式，识别文本的可读性。
2. 通过系统的学术写作训练，发掘学生的写作潜能，增强学术写作意识，并合理分析不同观点。这种通过写作任务带动阅读的方式，是“产出导向法”的精髓，也收到了较好的效果。
3. 通过适当的概述原文训练，提高学生获取信息的能力，增强文本的衔接与连贯。
4. 通过课外牛津阅读和推荐书单阅读，扩大学生的知识面，加强学生的批判思维能力。
5. 通过课外推荐听力材料，巩固学生的学术听力水平，拓展同主题的相关知识。

大学英语IV

课程编码：B15GB004Y 英文名称：College English IV 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：-

教学目的要求
按照教育部2017年最新版的大学英语教学指南，大学英语IV遵循较高要求，通过课堂教学和课外辅导提高学术英语写作水平。
1. 以“学术语境(B)—研究问题/假设(P)—解决方案(S)—合理性评估(E)”为线索，通过“问题导向”激发学生的兴趣和自主学习能力，提升学生从事学术研究的成就感。
2. 通过学术英语词汇体系建设，提高学生的学术词汇搭配能力和准确性。
3. 通过学术英语文本分析，帮助学生掌握学术语言的五大功能，从而培养批判性思维能力。
4. 通过学术英语写作训练，加强学生的读者意识，增强学生讲好学术故事的信心。
5. 通过小组合作和阶段性汇报，激发团队合作精神，培养人际沟通能力。

预修课程

主要内容

1. Academic structure and academic style

2. Referencing

3. Synthesizing ideas

4. Evaluative language

5. Nominalization

6. Hedging expressions

 

 

课时分配

除第一周进行课程描述外，每周均有特定的语言要点和学术素养技巧，按照各自项目的进展，步步深入。第1-5周为选题和文献回顾，第6-7周为提出问题和研究设计，第8-10周为解决问题和结果描述，第11-15周为讨论与评估。第16周进行小组研究口头汇报，同时提交课程论文作为期末评分的依据。

 

考核方式：

平时成绩占60%，期末论文40%。

课程思政
大学英语IV本着学术诚信的原则，鼓励学生们合作共赢（Chapter 2-1 Why We Cooperate）、求同存异。通过大量的案例教学，让学生识别科学与伪科学（Chapter 1-1 The Magic of Reality 及Chapter 5-1 Experimentation），理解科学伦理（Chapter 4-2 Harvesting Human Organs from Pigs 及 Chapter 8-1 Why Frankenstein is a Stigma among Scientists），树立诚信为本，科学报国的原则。同时，该课程的项目驱动式教学鼓励学思结合、知行统一，有助于增强学生勇于探索的创新精神、善于解决问题的实践能力。

《通用学术英语综合教程（读写）》，2020，北京：外语教学与研究出版社。

《大学英语教学指南（2017）》，中华人民共和国教育部编。

中国科学院大学外语系讲师，2014年获英国格拉斯哥大学英语语言文学硕士学位，2018年获澳大利亚新南威尔士大学英语语言文学博士学位。主要研究方向为应用语言学研究 (Applied Linguistics), 二语习得研究 (Second Language Acquisition), 学术英语研究 (English for Academic Purposes)。 2018年参与美国应用语言学芝加哥会议并作以“L1 in the IRF cycle: A case study of Chinese EFL/ESL classrooms”为主题的报告，2017年参与世界应用语言学里约热内卢会议并作以“Investigating IRF cycle from moves to discourse: A comparative study of Chinese and Australian classrooms”为主题的报告。已发表论文7篇。

陈莫
中国科学院大学外语系讲师。2012年获美国卡内基梅隆大学应用第二语言习得硕士学位，2019年获美国爱荷华州立大学应用语言学与技术博士学位。主要研究方向为语料库，项目型语言学习和语言测试。

其它说明

大学英语IV

课程编码：B15GB004Y-01 英文名称：College English IV 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共必修课 主讲教师：李婧雅

教学目的要求
按照教育部2017年最新版的大学英语教学指南，大学英语IV遵循较高要求，通过课堂教学和课外辅导提高学术英语写作水平。
1. 以“学术语境(B)—研究问题/假设(P)—解决方案(S)—合理性评估(E)”为线索，通过“问题导向”激发学生的兴趣和自主学习能力，提升学生从事学术研究的成就感。
2. 通过学术英语词汇体系建设，提高学生的学术词汇搭配能力和准确性。
3. 通过学术英语文本分析，帮助学生掌握学术语言的五大功能，从而培养批判性思维能力。
4. 通过学术英语写作训练，加强学生的读者意识，增强学生讲好学术故事的信心。
5. 通过小组合作和阶段性汇报，激发团队合作精神，培养人际沟通能力。

预修课程

主要内容

1. Academic structure and academic style

2. Referencing

3. Synthesizing ideas

4. Evaluative language

5. Nominalization

6. Hedging expressions

 

课时分配

除第一周进行课程描述外，每周均有特定的语言要点和学术素养技巧，按照各自项目的进展，步步深入。第1-5周为选题和文献回顾，第6-7周为提出问题和研究设计，第8-10周为解决问题和结果描述，第11-15周为讨论与评估。第16周进行小组研究口头汇报，同时提交课程论文作为期末评分的依据。

 

考核方式：

平时成绩占60%，期末论文40%。

课程思政
大学英语IV本着学术诚信的原则，鼓励学生们合作共赢（Chapter 2-1 Why We Cooperate）、求同存异。通过大量的案例教学，让学生识别科学与伪科学（Chapter 1-1 The Magic of Reality 及Chapter 5-1 Experimentation），理解科学伦理（Chapter 4-2 Harvesting Human Organs from Pigs 及 Chapter 8-1 Why Frankenstein is a Stigma among Scientists），树立诚信为本，科学报国的原则。同时，该课程的项目驱动式教学鼓励学思结合、知行统一，有助于增强学生勇于探索的创新精神、善于解决问题的实践能力。

教学目的要求
As China continues to develop its connections in many fields, English Public Speaking is becoming increasingly important. The opportunity and necessity for public speaking in English are expanding in science, technology, politics, business, law, journalism, and in most fields of education. It is no longer enough to simply study English or Oral English, the time has come to develop the skills of communication both with individuals as well as large groups of people and this is what Public Speaking can help you achieve.

预修课程

主要内容

This class will teach about the variety of types of speeches – prepared speeches where you have a longer time to prepare and impromptu where your preparation is confined to a matter of minutes. We will study how to organize your thoughts, write speeches as well as the art of delivering them to secure the maximum effect. We will deal with the different goals of speeches and the importance of focusing on those goals. Other matters to be covered include the importance of your audience, the proper use of language and appropriate use of visual aids. You will be responsible for presenting several presentations, some of which will require you to do research. Finally, you will learn the importance of time in public speaking.

课程编码：B15GX015Y-01 英文名称：Media Literacy 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Ann Marie Joan Laskiewicz-Ross

教学目的要求
In Media Literacy, the student will learn to:
1) read/view/listen and evaluate news articles, TV coverage, photos, short videos, and different media that is written or spoken in English
2) understand the different demands and restrictions on news gatherers and media distributors
3) analyze and evaluate information from contemporary media to properly formulate a written paper in English on a factual topic, using available, reliable sources.

预修课程

主要内容

The Media Literacy course is designed to help UCAS undergraduate students better understand the information media, which due to people’s greater literacy and the Internet, is more powerful and influential than ever before. The choices for today’s students range from established newspapers and TV to newly risen self-made bloggers, from fake news to colorful info graphics, from celebrity news to live broadcasts of disasters and war, from hour-long documentaries to news-bites that are barely a minute long.

Most classes will end with a 20 minute student-led discussion on a prearranged topic. In week 5, students will be assigned to/or chose/ a topic “beat.” In week 8 in small groups/news team, they will together begin working on one project. Individual tasks for this multimedia project will be assigned and graded at 10% for rough draft; 20% for final. Two quizzes, short writing assignments, and a final test also are part of the grade.

Attendance is mandatory. More than 3 absences for any reason mean you fail the course and receive no credit.

The English and thinking skills to be improved include greater speed in scanning print media, writing to interest readers, finding and assessing reliable sources, using academic sources, and critical thinking

Week

2 Media coverage

3 News staff and their Beats

4 Time: Its overwhelming importance in the news field

5 Money, Eyeballs, & Shock Value: News is a Business

6 Fake News

7 Audio

8 Trends: A Nose for News

9 Limitations

10 Spin

11 Science News is Big News

12 Workshop on Small-Group Project

13 OMG—Don’t read that!

14 Review of Current News Events/Student choice

15 Is this News?

16 Conclusion

考核方式：

Grades:

25%- Beat Writing/journal assignments

10%- 2 Quizzes (20 min.) 5 pts. each

25%-Test

10%-Rough draft of project

20%-Final project

10%-Participation includes attendance, tardiness, homework, and preparation for student’s active engagement in classroom discussion.

教材

课程编码：B15GX017Y-01 英文名称：Speaking in Academic Scenarios 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Sam Seery

教学目的要求
This module builds on the foundational English language training for second year undergraduate students at the University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. This integrated module aims to provide students with a solid foundation in academic English speaking as well as a working knowledge of the dynamics of academic scenarios.
Module learning outcomes:
On completion of this module students will be able to:
? design academic presentations
? analyse the dynamics of most academic scenarios
? understand academic etiquette
? have the confidence to engage in academic presentations

预修课程

主要内容

The weekly timetabled teaching will mix lectures, exercises, and interactive tutorials, but it is also expected that students will devote additional private study time to this course. 教学目的要求
This course is designed for non-English major undergraduate students. It introduces students to classical British and American writers and literary works. Students will enjoy reading, gain basic knowledge of literary history, and know how to appreciate or criticize a literary work better. Students will also improve their reading, speaking and writing abilities in the process.

预修课程

主要内容

Reading will be assigned every week. Discussions, presentations and other activities will be included. A term paper is also required.

课时分配

Week 1 - Lecture: Introduction

Week 2 - Lecture: Shakespeare (I)

Week 3 - Lecture: Shakespeare (II)

Week 4 - Lecture: Shakespeare (III)

Week 5 - Lecture: Robert Burns

Week 6 - Lecture: William Wordsworth 

Week 7 - Lecture: Walt Whitman 

Week 8 - Lecture: Emily Dickinson

Week 9 - Lecture: Jane Austen

Week 10 - Student Group Project

Week 11 - Lecture: Charlotte Brontë

Week 12 - Lecture: Charles Dickens

Week 13 - Lecture: Virginia Woolf

Week 14 - Lecture: Benjamin Franklin

Week 15 - Lecture: Henry David Thoreau

Week 16 - Lecture: Say Goodbye 

 

考核方式：

Attendance-5%

Class performance-5%

Written assignment -10%

Presentations and class activities-20%

Mid-term group project-10%

Term paper -50% 

课程思政
经典文学作品是历经时间沉淀的人类文明之瑰宝，引导学生阅读和思考文学作品，乃培养青年人丰富精神和健康情操之良方。本课程旨在帮助学生明辨善恶（如：莎士比亚戏剧），关照内心和外部世界（如：浪漫主义诗歌），培养坚毅品格和树立积极人生观（如：18至20世纪小说），审视物质生活和精神追求的关系（如：《瓦尔登湖》），探究科学和人文的奇妙关联，等等。通过合理引导，帮助学生提高审美能力，增进人文素养，锻炼心智品格。

教材
1. Wang, Shouren, et al. eds. Selected Readings in British Literature. 4th ed. Beijing: Higher Education Press, 2014.
[王守仁主编：《英国文学选读》（第四版），北京：高等教育出版社，2014年。]
2. Tao Jie, et al. eds.Selected Readings in American Literature. 3rd ed. Beijing: Higher Education Press, 2011.
[陶洁主编：《美国文学选读》（第三版），北京：高等教育出版社，2011年。]

参考文献

课程教师信息
Dr. Xiong Jingya is associate professor of English at UCAS, specializing in modern and contemporary British and American literature. She also lectures on British and American modernist literature, the twentieth-century British novel and public speaking in English. Her recent publications include “Origin and Connotations of Leavis’s ‘Criticism in Practice’” (Foreign Literatures 3 (2018)), “Literary Canon and Cultural Continuity: Leavis’s Construction of the ‘Living Tradition’”(Interdisciplinary Studies of Literature 1 (2018)), and “Leavis’s View of Poetic Language”(Foreign Literature Review 1(2017)).

课程编码：B15GX022Y-01 英文名称：Public Speaking II 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：侯大千

教学目的要求
本课程旨在通过课堂教学和课外辅导，讲授英语基本演讲类型、演讲技巧、分析演讲实例，让学生全方位了解英语公共演讲，掌握公共演讲基本表达及讲稿撰写。具体目的和要求如下：
1. 通过课堂讨论和实例学习，培养学生的英语表达能力、语言欣赏能力、语言实际运用能力和英语演讲能力；
2. 通过丰富多样的演讲话题以及课堂讨论，培养学生使用英语进行思辨和沟通的能力；
3. 通过训练，使学生学会演讲稿的撰写方法，提高在公共场合演讲能力。
4. 通过信息性演讲（informative speech）的讲授和练习，培养学生在公共场合中使用英文表达、介绍、传递信息的能力，尤其是培养学生使用英文表达、传递学术性专业知识的能力。
5. 通过说服性演讲（persuasive speech）的讲授和练习，培养学生的思辨思维、语言表达能力以及调动各种非语言因素进行表达的能力。

预修课程

主要内容

1. Informative speech

  • How to write different parts
  • How to draw an outline
  • Speech writing and delivery

2. Persuasive speech

  • Critical thinking

  • Outline drawing and speech writing

课程思政
通过对于文化、经济、道德、法律、性别等板块的演讲问题的讨论，本课程帮助学生了解社会、了解世界、拓宽视野、增长知识。通过对时下的社会热点问题进行讨论并提出解决方法，培养学生对社会的关心，提高共情能力以及热爱祖国，关心人类共同体的情感。同时，提高学生观察问题、分析问题、解决问题的能力。为学生毕业后适应社会、融入社会，更好地奉献社会提前打好基础。

教学目的要求
本课程旨在通过课堂教学和课外辅导，讲授英语基本演讲类型、演讲技巧、分析演讲实例，让学生全方位了解英语公共演讲，掌握公共演讲基本表达及讲稿撰写。具体目的和要求如下：
1. 通过课堂讨论和实例学习，培养学生的英语表达能力、语言欣赏能力、语言实际运用能力和英语演讲能力；
2. 通过丰富多样的演讲话题以及课堂讨论，培养学生使用英语进行思辨和沟通的能力；

课程编码：B15GX024Y-01 英文名称：Greek and Roman Mythology 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：龚世琳等

教学目的要求
To establish a sound grasp of terms and concepts commonly accepted and practiced in the fields of literature, anthropology and cultural studies needed to construct a general framework for mythology.

预修课程

主要内容

Greek and Roman mythology offer insight into the world view as well as cosmological view of early Europeans. At the same time, inquiries into the origins and structures of ancient Greek and Roman mythology can serve as a point of departure to question the principles, universal norms as well as breadth of mythology worldwide. Reading and discussing the stories of specific mythological creatures or gods such as Theseus, Zeus, Jupiter or Luna amongst others serves as a point of departure for a few different kinds of insightful analysis: What function did these stories have amongst ancient people? Based on the accounts of ancient Greeks and Romans, what can we access about the cosmological as well as world view of people at the time? What symbolic and ethical details may have these stories and characters embodied? Other than historical knowledge and insight, what value may these mythologies offer to contemporary humanity?

      To more fully discuss possible answers to these questions, we must also implore concrete examples of mythology. There are no limitations to cross comparison of different mythologies; however, in order to complete the task of exploring the aforementioned questions in the context of a semester long course, each week one grouping of Roman mythology as well one grouping of Greek mythology will be cross compared with one or two mythological groupings stemming from non-Roman/non-Greek cultures. This requires presentation from the point of view of the course instructor as well as input from students based on out of class review of reading materials. Each weekly lecture and in class discussion will gradually emphasize yet another series of valued questions such as: What are the most unique aspects of Ancient Roman and Greek mythology? What common effects may diverse mythologies have on members of societies? What is the importance of being knowledgeable about the world of mythology in order to understand the potential of human imagination?

详细内容:
从舞台到银幕：文学经典与流行文化

课程编码：B15GX037Y-01 英文名称：From Stage to Screen: Literacy Classics and Popular Culture 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：安帅

教学目的要求
This course is designed for non-English major undergraduate students. It aims to provide students with new perspectives of appreciating canonical English and American literary works. Students will enjoy themselves through linking literary classics with popular culture, thus lessening the general sense of distance between serious literature and real life due to the gaps of time and space. By getting in touch with some of the greatest minds in human history, they will embark on a journey of literature that is both fun and enriching. They will learn to become critical and experienced readers and their perception of the contemporary Western society and culture may be sharpened with the newly-gained lens of literary classics. In the meantime, their English language proficiency can be enhanced during the process.

预修课程

主要内容

The body of this course consists of three parts. To begin with, students will get to know the genre of drama, embracing its lasting attractions both as a literary form and as a performing art on stage. Next, the focus will be shifted to the genre of fiction—novels that are closely related to popular culture: science fiction, crime fiction and sports fiction. Besides, at least three films will be analyzed in terms of their interactions with literary traditionsand contemporary culture.

Students are required to proactively participate in class activities. They are encouraged to form small groups to reenact certain parts of the plays concerned or make adaptations. They can also try to do film dubbing. Another way to get involved is to give an oral report or presentation. A term paper is required based on the works and topics discussed in class.

课时分配

Week 1 Introduction

Week 2 English Drama I: Christopher Marlowe, Doctor Faustus

Week 3 English Drama II: William Shakespeare, The Tempest

Week 4 English Drama III: Oscar Wilde, Salome

Week 5 Film I: Gone with the Wind (1939); Django Unchained (2012)

Week 6 American Drama I: Eugene O’Neil, Long Day’s Journey into Night

Week 7 American Drama II: Arthur Miller, The Crucible

Week 8 American Drama III: Lorraine Hansberry, A Raisin in the Sun

Week 9Film II: Joy Luck Club (1993); The Farewell (2019)

Week 10 Science Fiction I: Mary Shelley, Frankenstein

Week 11 Science Fiction II: Robert Louis Stevenson, Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde 

Week 12 Crime Fiction I: Edgar Allan Poe, “The Tell-Tale Heart” 

Week 13Crime Fiction II: Raymond Chandler, “Red Wind”

Week 14 Film III: Taxi Driver (1976); Three Billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri (2017)

Week 15 Sports Fiction I: Ernest Hemingway and others, excerpts  

Week 16 Sports Fiction II: Philip Roth and others, excerpts

考核方式：

Regular class attendance (10%), active participation in class discussion (10%), a presentation OR five dubbed film excerpts*(20%), and an essay of approximately 800 words* (60%), in English.

课程思政
Whereas literary classics are the treasuresthrough which dialogues between contemporary human beings and the greatest minds in human history can take place, resulting in a better understanding of the law of nature (e.g. romanticism), the pursuit of knowledge (e.g. Dr. Faustus and Dr. Jekyll) and beauty (e.g. aestheticism), and the complexities of the way of the world (e.g. Shakespeare), an anatomy of popular culture can lead to the demystification of current issues (e.g. racism and feminism), making students aware of the ideals shared by mankind (e.g. the inner peace veterans seek and the justice Django fights for) as well as the possibilities of a better world.

教材
Selected readings of English and American literature will be compiled and edited by the instructor and handed out to students. Access to the films and video clips to be analyzed will also be provided before class.

课程教师信息
Dr. An Shuai is Lecturer of English at UCAS, specializing in narrative and the novel. He also lectures on the 19th-century English novel. His recent publications include “Narrative History as Games of Chess and Space: The Covert Progression in Libra” (Foreign Literature Studies1[2019]: 28-37),“Collision between Sense and Sensibility behind Race-Centered Conflict: Covert Progression in Wolff’s ‘Say Yes’” (Foreign Literature Studies3[2017]:104-111).

课程编码：B15GX027Y-01 英文名称：World Literature and Composition 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Ann Marie Joan Laskiewicz-Ross

教学目的要求
World Literature and Composition is designed to help UCAS undergraduate students become more informed about literary styles in English, to appreciate stories and literature, and to enjoy reading them.
We will read some recent short pieces from modern world literature and take a look at the differences in writing styles. Students will use what they learn to improve their own writing.
Since globalization and interacting with other countries will impact students’ future success, the course emphasis is on literary and cultural appreciation. That means we will be reading and reacting to stories from many different countries, a Ray Bradbury science fiction story from the US, a short story from India, some Chinese fiction, a Latin American magical realism story. (But, because this is not “a survey course,” we will not have time to read old classics, entire Shakespearean plays, or big Russian novels.)
Students will be assessed on their ability to understand the reading material (50%) and express higher level thinking (50%).

预修课程

主要内容

Formal Objectives: In World Literature and Composition, the student will:

1) read and comprehend short pieces of fiction written in English,

2) use writing to react to readings and to recognize how culture and personal experience shape the way a person writes,

3) analyze a literary work according to its theme,

4) increase English writing proficiency including improving overall structure and linking the ideas.

The English reading, writing and thinking skills to be improved include greater speed in scanning printed material, writing with greater clarity and higher level vocabulary, research, and critical thinking at the level of abstract ideas. Attendance is mandatory.

课时分配

1) Introduction: What exactly is World Literature?

2) Foundations: The ‘sound’ of the alphabet.

3) Overall View: Modern world literature today

4) Meet some authors

5) Themes: We tell ourselves stories to learn how to live

6) What a character!

7) Lexical levels

8) Diversity—Meeting a new culture/ “The other”

9) Plot and what telling the plot can and cannot do

10) For some people, reading World Literature means reading a book in translation

11) Where does Chinese fiction fit in?

13) Magical Realism. When fiction is really fictional, where is the truth in it?

14) Workshop on improving your writing

15) Final themes/ Review

16) Conclusion

 

考核方式：

Grades: Grades will be based on 2 quizzes, a test, short writing assignments, a 3-page paper, and participation.

课程思政

教材

Students will be given handouts or e-material, and required to read or watch specific items available from the Internet.

Prof. Ross holds a bachelor’s degree in English literature, a master’s degree in communications from Columbia University, a master’s degree in education, and a postgraduate degree in African studies including literature and history. Before beginning to teach in college and in the Pennsylvania public school system in the USA, she earned her living as a professional writer and editor. 教学目的要求
This course is designed for non-English major undergraduate students. It aims to provide students with new perspectives of appreciating canonical English and American literary works. Students will enjoy themselves through linking literary classics with popular culture, thus lessening the general sense of distance between serious literature and real life due to the gaps of time and space. By getting in touch with some of the greatest minds in human history, they will embark on a journey of literature that is both fun and enriching. They will learn to become critical and experienced readers and their perception of the contemporary Western society and culture may be sharpened with the newly-gained lens of literary classics. In the meantime, their English language proficiency can be enhanced during the process.

预修课程

主要内容

The body of this course consists of three parts. To begin with, students will get to know the genre of drama, embracing its lasting attractions both as a literary form and as a performing art on stage. Next, the focus will be shifted to the genre of fiction—novels that are closely related to popular culture: science fiction, crime fiction and sports fiction. Besides, at least three films will be analyzed in terms of their interactions with literary traditionsand contemporary culture.

Students are required to proactively participate in class activities. They are encouraged to form small groups to reenact certain parts of the plays concerned or make adaptations. They can also try to do film dubbing. Another way to get involved is to give an oral report or presentation. A term paper is required based on the works and topics discussed in class.

教学目的要求
This course is designed to help students to:
understand the fundamental principles of good science-related writing;

预修课程

主要内容

Science Reading is a learner-centered course at the basic level to help students develop academic reading and writing skills, with focus on developing long-term skills, rather than short-term, exam-centered knowledge acquisition. During the semester, students are exposed to a wide range of articles and book chapters covering science and society. In this course, high-quality reading and writing will be fostered through students’ self-learning before and after class. In class, the teaching team focuses on fostering critical thinking and discussion of the weekly reading material, as well as analyzing content-related summary writing completed by the participating students.

Please note: this course does NOT use original research articles published in academic journals; instead, this course uses science-related texts that are easily understood by our students studying in a wide range of different disciplines.

Attendance and Participation

Active participation in class and completion of all tasks are essential to your success in this course, and play a major role in grading. Failure in completing a task will result in loss of points contributing to your final score. Importantly, it is crucial that you only take this class if you are certain that you can complete the reading required for this course.  

If you are absent, it is your responsibility to come to the next class prepared. You need to contact the TA or fellow classmates to get up-to-date information about assignments you have missed. In class, you ARE allowed to use Cellphones, iPads and Computers, for the purpose of completing any task given during class. You are explicitly requested to bring science books of interest. 

 

Academic Honesty Policy

As members of the academic community, students are expected to recognize and uphold standards of intellectual and academic integrity. Here are some basic rules that will be observed in this class and a description of the University’s honesty policy: 

Cheating: Any student caught cheating on an exam or a test will be invited to leave the class and not return. 

Plagiarism: Any plagiarized work will receive the grade of zero and the student will receive a warning. Students who repeatedly plagiarize texts will be invited to drop the class.

Academic dishonesty occurs in the following forms: (1) cheating on examinations, (2) plagiarism, (3) unauthorized collaboration, (4) falsification, and (5) multiple submissions.

课程编码：B15GX031Y-02 英文名称：Science Reading for Future Academics 课时：32 学分：2.00 课程属性：公共选修课 主讲教师：Torsten Juelich

教学目的要求
This course is designed to help students to:
understand the fundamental principles of good science-related writing;
foster weekly reading and writing activities;
learn how to read with focus on both content and grammar;
recognize patterns of good science-related writing;
develop skills required for summarizing content information;

预修课程

主要内容

Science Reading is a learner-centered course at the basic level to help students develop academic reading and writing skills, with focus on developing long-term skills, rather than short-term, exam-centered knowledge acquisition. During the semester, students are exposed to a wide range of articles and book chapters covering science and society. In this course, high-quality reading and writing will be fostered through students’ self-learning before and after class. In class, the teaching team focuses on fostering critical thinking and discussion of the weekly reading material, as well as analyzing content-related summary writing completed by the participating students.

Please note: this course does NOT use original research articles published in academic journals; instead, this course uses science-related texts that are easily understood by our students studying in a wide range of different disciplines.

 

Attendance and Participation

Active participation in class and completion of all tasks are essential to your success in this course, and play a major role in grading. Failure in completing a task will result in loss of points contributing to your final score. Importantly, it is crucial that you only take this class if you are certain that you can complete the reading required for this course.  

If you are absent, it is your responsibility to come to the next class prepared. You need to contact the TA or fellow classmates to get up-to-date information about assignments you have missed. In class, you ARE allowed to use Cellphones, iPads and Computers, for the purpose of completing any task given during class. You are explicitly requested to bring science books of interest. 

 

Academic Honesty Policy

As members of the academic community, students are expected to recognize and uphold standards of intellectual and academic integrity. Here are some basic rules that will be observed in this class and a description of the University’s honesty policy: 

Cheating: Any student caught cheating on an exam or a test will be invited to leave the class and not return. 

Plagiarism: Any plagiarized work will receive the grade of zero and the student will receive a warning. Students who repeatedly plagiarize texts will be invited to drop the class.

Academic dishonesty occurs in the following forms: (1) cheating on examinations, (2) plagiarism, (3) unauthorized collaboration, (4) falsification, and (5) multiple submissions.

教学目的要求
This debate course is designed to develop the student’s ability to support and present logical and persuasive argument. Students will learn the standards of debate and the valuable skills of argumentation that will assist them with their educational careers and beyond. There will be a particular focus on the British Parliamentary Debate style, with the intention of preparing students for competitive debates.

预修课程

主要内容

Introduce general principles of debate including public speaking, create clear and persuasive arguments, and issue rebuttals; introduce the different roles in British Parliamentary Debate, including theory and specific practice.

 

 

课时分配

This course will be organized according to the following schedule:

Weeks 1-6: Introduction to general principles of debate including public speaking, creating clear and persuasive arguments, and issuing rebuttals.

Weeks 7-12: Introduction to the different roles in British Parliamentary Debate, including theory and specific practice.

Weeks 13-16: Intensive practice in debate format.

考核方式：50% participation and 50% final debate challenge.
